segment.source: Use Windows Event Forwarding to help with intrusion detection (Windows 10)
segment.target: Use Windows Event Forwarding to help with intrusion detection (Windows 10)

segment.source: Learn about an approach to collect events from devices in your organization.
segment.target: Learn about an approach to collect events from devices in your organization.

segment.source: This article talks about events in both normal operations and when an intrusion is suspected.
segment.target: This article talks about events in both normal operations and when an intrusion is suspected.

segment.source: Use Windows Event Forwarding to help with intrusion detection
segment.target: Use Windows Event Forwarding to help with intrusion detection

segment.source: Applies to
segment.target: Applies to

segment.source: Windows 10
segment.target: Windows 10

segment.source: Learn about an approach to collect events from devices in your organization.
segment.target: Learn about an approach to collect events from devices in your organization.

segment.source: This article talks about events in both normal operations and when an intrusion is suspected.
segment.target: This article talks about events in both normal operations and when an intrusion is suspected.

segment.source: Windows Event Forwarding (WEF) reads any operational or administrative event log on a device in your organization and forwards the events you choose to a Windows Event Collector (WEC) server.
segment.target: Windows Event Forwarding (WEF) reads any operational or administrative event log on a device in your organization and forwards the events you choose to a Windows Event Collector (WEC) server.

segment.source: To accomplish this, there are two different of subscriptions published to client devices - the Baseline subscription and the suspect subscription.
segment.target: To accomplish this, there are two different of subscriptions published to client devices - the Baseline subscription and the suspect subscription.

segment.source: The Baseline subscription enrolls all devices in your organization, and a Suspect subscription only includes devices that have been added by you.
segment.target: The Baseline subscription enrolls all devices in your organization, and a Suspect subscription only includes devices that have been added by you.

segment.source: The Suspect subscription collects additional events to help build context for system activity and can quickly be updated to accommodate new events and/or scenarios as needed without impacting baseline operations.
segment.target: The Suspect subscription collects additional events to help build context for system activity and can quickly be updated to accommodate new events and/or scenarios as needed without impacting baseline operations.

segment.source: This implementation helps differentiate where events are ultimately stored.
segment.target: This implementation helps differentiate where events are ultimately stored.

segment.source: Baseline events can be sent to devices with online analytical capability, such as Security Event Manager (SEM), while also sending events to a MapReduce system, such as HDInsight or Hadoop, for long-term storage and deeper analysis.
segment.target: Baseline events can be sent to devices with online analytical capability, such as Security Event Manager (SEM), while also sending events to a MapReduce system, such as HDInsight or Hadoop, for long-term storage and deeper analysis.

segment.source: Events from the Suspect subscription are sent directly to a MapReduce system due to volume and lower signal/noise ratio, they are largely used for host forensic analysis.
segment.target: Events from the Suspect subscription are sent directly to a MapReduce system due to volume and lower signal/noise ratio, they are largely used for host forensic analysis.

segment.source: An SEM’s strength lies in being able to inspect, correlate events, and generate alerts for known patterns manner and alert security staff at machine speed.
segment.target: An SEM’s strength lies in being able to inspect, correlate events, and generate alerts for known patterns manner and alert security staff at machine speed.

segment.source: A MapReduce system has a longer retention time (years versus months for an SEM), larger ingress ability (hundreds of terabytes per day), and the ability to perform more complex operations on the data like statistical and trend analysis, pattern clustering analysis, or apply Machine Learning algorithms.
segment.target: A MapReduce system has a longer retention time (years versus months for an SEM), larger ingress ability (hundreds of terabytes per day), and the ability to perform more complex operations on the data like statistical and trend analysis, pattern clustering analysis, or apply Machine Learning algorithms.

segment.source: Here's an approximate scaling guide for WEF events:
segment.target: Here's an approximate scaling guide for WEF events:

segment.source: Events/second range
segment.target: Events/second range

segment.source: Data store
segment.target: Data store

segment.source: SQL or SEM
segment.target: SQL or SEM

segment.source: SEM
segment.target: SEM

segment.source: Hadoop/HDInsight/Data Lake
segment.target: Hadoop/HDInsight/Data Lake

segment.source: Event generation on a device must be enabled either separately or as part of the GPO for the baseline WEF implementation, including enabling of disabled event logs and setting channel permissions.
segment.target: Event generation on a device must be enabled either separately or as part of the GPO for the baseline WEF implementation, including enabling of disabled event logs and setting channel permissions.

segment.source: For more info, see Appendix C - Event channel settings (enable and channel access) methods.
segment.target: For more info, see Appendix C - Event channel settings (enable and channel access) methods.

segment.source: This is because WEF is a passive system with regards to the event log.
segment.target: This is because WEF is a passive system with regards to the event log.

segment.source: It cannot change the size of event log files, enable disabled event channels, change channel permissions, or adjust a security audit policy.
segment.target: It cannot change the size of event log files, enable disabled event channels, change channel permissions, or adjust a security audit policy.

segment.source: WEF only queries event channels for existing events.
segment.target: WEF only queries event channels for existing events.

segment.source: Additionally, having event generation already occurring on a device allows for more complete event collection building a complete history of system activity.
segment.target: Additionally, having event generation already occurring on a device allows for more complete event collection building a complete history of system activity.

segment.source: Otherwise, you'll be limited to the speed of GPO and WEF subscription refresh cycles to make changes to what is being generated on the device.
segment.target: Otherwise, you'll be limited to the speed of GPO and WEF subscription refresh cycles to make changes to what is being generated on the device.

segment.source: On modern devices, enabling additional event channels and expanding the size of event log files has not resulted in noticeable performance differences.
segment.target: On modern devices, enabling additional event channels and expanding the size of event log files has not resulted in noticeable performance differences.

segment.source: For the minimum recommended audit policy and registry system ACL settings, see Appendix A - Minimum recommended minimum audit policy and Appendix B - Recommended minimum registry system ACL policy.
segment.target: For the minimum recommended audit policy and registry system ACL settings, see Appendix A - Minimum recommended minimum audit policy and Appendix B - Recommended minimum registry system ACL policy.

segment.source: Note: These are only minimum values need to meet what the WEF subscription selects.
segment.target: Note: These are only minimum values need to meet what the WEF subscription selects.

segment.source: From a WEF subscription management perspective, the event queries provided should be used in two separate subscriptions for ease of maintenance; only machines meeting specific criteria would be allowed access to the targeted subscription, this access would be determined by an algorithm or an analysts’ direction.
segment.target: From a WEF subscription management perspective, the event queries provided should be used in two separate subscriptions for ease of maintenance; only machines meeting specific criteria would be allowed access to the targeted subscription, this access would be determined by an algorithm or an analysts’ direction.

segment.source: All devices should have access to the Baseline subscription.
segment.target: All devices should have access to the Baseline subscription.

segment.source: This means you would create two base subscriptions:
segment.target: This means you would create two base subscriptions:

segment.source: Baseline WEF subscription.
segment.target: Baseline WEF subscription.

segment.source: Events collected from all hosts, this includes some role-specific events, which will only be emitted by those machines.
segment.target: Events collected from all hosts, this includes some role-specific events, which will only be emitted by those machines.

segment.source: Targeted WEF subscription.
segment.target: Targeted WEF subscription.

segment.source: Events collected from a limited set of hosts due to unusual activity and/or heightened awareness for those systems.
segment.target: Events collected from a limited set of hosts due to unusual activity and/or heightened awareness for those systems.

segment.source: Each using the respective event query below.
segment.target: Each using the respective event query below.

segment.source: Note that for the Targeted subscription enabling the “read existing events” option should be set to true to allow collection of existing events from systems.
segment.target: Note that for the Targeted subscription enabling the “read existing events” option should be set to true to allow collection of existing events from systems.

segment.source: By default, WEF subscriptions will only forward events generated after the WEF subscription was received by the client.
segment.target: By default, WEF subscriptions will only forward events generated after the WEF subscription was received by the client.

segment.source: In Appendix E – Annotated Baseline Subscription Event Query and Appendix F – Annotated Suspect Subscription Event Query, the event query XML is included when creating WEF subscriptions.
segment.target: In Appendix E – Annotated Baseline Subscription Event Query and Appendix F – Annotated Suspect Subscription Event Query, the event query XML is included when creating WEF subscriptions.

segment.source: These are annotated for query purpose and clarity.
segment.target: These are annotated for query purpose and clarity.

segment.source: Individual Query element can be removed or edited without affecting the rest of the query.
segment.target: Individual Query element can be removed or edited without affecting the rest of the query.

segment.source: Common WEF questions
segment.target: Common WEF questions

segment.source: This section addresses common questions from IT pros and customers.
segment.target: This section addresses common questions from IT pros and customers.

segment.source: Will the user notice if their machine is enabled for WEF or if WEF encounters an error?
segment.target: Will the user notice if their machine is enabled for WEF or if WEF encounters an error?

segment.source: The short answer is: No.
segment.target: The short answer is: No.

segment.source: The longer answer is: The Eventlog-forwardingPlugin/Operational event channel logs the success, warning, and error events related to WEF subscriptions present on the device.
segment.target: The longer answer is: The Eventlog-forwardingPlugin/Operational event channel logs the success, warning, and error events related to WEF subscriptions present on the device.

segment.source: Unless the user opens Event Viewer and navigates to that channel, they will not notice WEF either through resource consumption or Graphical User Interface pop-ups.
segment.target: Unless the user opens Event Viewer and navigates to that channel, they will not notice WEF either through resource consumption or Graphical User Interface pop-ups.

segment.source: Even if there is an issue with the WEF subscription, there is no user interaction or performance degradation.
segment.target: Even if there is an issue with the WEF subscription, there is no user interaction or performance degradation.

segment.source: All success, warning, and failure events are logged to this operational event channel.
segment.target: All success, warning, and failure events are logged to this operational event channel.

segment.source: Is WEF Push or Pull?
segment.target: Is WEF Push or Pull?

segment.source: A WEF subscription can be configured to be push or pull, but not both.
segment.target: A WEF subscription can be configured to be push or pull, but not both.

segment.source: The simplest, most flexible IT deployment with the greatest scalability can be achieved by using a push, or source initiated, subscription.
segment.target: The simplest, most flexible IT deployment with the greatest scalability can be achieved by using a push, or source initiated, subscription.

segment.source: WEF clients are configured by using a GPO and the built-in forwarding client is activated.
segment.target: WEF clients are configured by using a GPO and the built-in forwarding client is activated.

segment.source: For pull, collector initiated, the subscription on the WEC server is pre-configured with the names of the WEF Client devices from which events are to be selected.
segment.target: For pull, collector initiated, the subscription on the WEC server is pre-configured with the names of the WEF Client devices from which events are to be selected.

segment.source: Those clients also have to be configured ahead of time to allow the credentials used in the subscription to access their event logs remotely (normally by adding the credential to the Event Log Readers built-in local security group.) A useful scenario: closely monitoring a specific set of machines.
segment.target: Those clients also have to be configured ahead of time to allow the credentials used in the subscription to access their event logs remotely (normally by adding the credential to the Event Log Readers built-in local security group.) A useful scenario: closely monitoring a specific set of machines.

segment.source: Will WEF work over VPN or RAS?
segment.target: Will WEF work over VPN or RAS?

segment.source: WEF handles VPN, RAS, and DirectAccess scenarios well and will reconnect and send any accumulated backlog of events when the connection to the WEF Collector is re-established.
segment.target: WEF handles VPN, RAS, and DirectAccess scenarios well and will reconnect and send any accumulated backlog of events when the connection to the WEF Collector is re-established.

segment.source: How is client progress tracked?
segment.target: How is client progress tracked?

segment.source: The WEC server maintains in its registry the bookmark information and last heartbeat time for each event source for each WEF subscription.
segment.target: The WEC server maintains in its registry the bookmark information and last heartbeat time for each event source for each WEF subscription.

segment.source: When an event source re-connects to a WEC server, the last bookmark position is sent to the device to use as a starting point to resume forwarding events.
segment.target: When an event source re-connects to a WEC server, the last bookmark position is sent to the device to use as a starting point to resume forwarding events.

segment.source: If a WEF client has no events to send, the WEF client will connect periodically to send a Heartbeat to the WEC server to indicate it is active.
segment.target: If a WEF client has no events to send, the WEF client will connect periodically to send a Heartbeat to the WEC server to indicate it is active.

segment.source: This heartbeat value can be individually configured for each subscription.
segment.target: This heartbeat value can be individually configured for each subscription.

segment.source: Will WEF work in an IPv4, IPv6, or mixed IPv4/IPv6 environment?
segment.target: Will WEF work in an IPv4, IPv6, or mixed IPv4/IPv6 environment?

segment.source: Yes.
segment.target: Yes.

segment.source: WEF is transport agnostic and will work over IPv4 or IPv6.
segment.target: WEF is transport agnostic and will work over IPv4 or IPv6.

segment.source: Are WEF events encrypted?
segment.target: Are WEF events encrypted?

segment.source: I see an HTTP/HTTPS option!
segment.target: I see an HTTP/HTTPS option!

segment.source: In a domain setting, the connection used to transmit WEF events is encrypted using Kerberos, by default (with NTLM as a fallback option, which can be disabled by using a GPO).
segment.target: In a domain setting, the connection used to transmit WEF events is encrypted using Kerberos, by default (with NTLM as a fallback option, which can be disabled by using a GPO).

segment.source: Only the WEF collector can decrypt the connection.
segment.target: Only the WEF collector can decrypt the connection.

segment.source: Additionally, the connection between WEF client and WEC server is mutually authenticated regardless of authentication type (Kerberos or NTLM.) There are GPO options to force Authentication to use Kerberos Only.
segment.target: Additionally, the connection between WEF client and WEC server is mutually authenticated regardless of authentication type (Kerberos or NTLM.) There are GPO options to force Authentication to use Kerberos Only.

segment.source: This authentication and encryption is performed regardless if HTTP or HTTPS is selected.
segment.target: This authentication and encryption is performed regardless if HTTP or HTTPS is selected.

segment.source: The HTTPS option is available if certificate based authentication is used, in cases where the Kerberos based mutual authentication is not an option.
segment.target: The HTTPS option is available if certificate based authentication is used, in cases where the Kerberos based mutual authentication is not an option.

segment.source: The SSL certificate and provisioned client certificates are used to provide mutual authentication.
segment.target: The SSL certificate and provisioned client certificates are used to provide mutual authentication.

segment.source: Do WEF Clients have a separate buffer for events?
segment.target: Do WEF Clients have a separate buffer for events?

segment.source: The WEF client machines local event log is the buffer for WEF for when the connection to the WEC server is lost.
segment.target: The WEF client machines local event log is the buffer for WEF for when the connection to the WEC server is lost.

segment.source: To increase the “buffer size”, increase the maximum file size of the specific event log file where events are being selected.
segment.target: To increase the “buffer size”, increase the maximum file size of the specific event log file where events are being selected.

segment.source: For more info, see Appendix C – Event Channel Settings (enable and Channel Access) methods.
segment.target: For more info, see Appendix C – Event Channel Settings (enable and Channel Access) methods.

segment.source: When the event log overwrites existing events (resulting in data loss if the device is not connected to the Event Collector), there is no notification sent to the WEF collector that events are lost from the client.
segment.target: When the event log overwrites existing events (resulting in data loss if the device is not connected to the Event Collector), there is no notification sent to the WEF collector that events are lost from the client.

segment.source: Neither is there an indicator that there was a gap encountered in the event stream.
segment.target: Neither is there an indicator that there was a gap encountered in the event stream.

segment.source: What format is used for forwarded events?
segment.target: What format is used for forwarded events?

segment.source: WEF has two modes for forwarded events.
segment.target: WEF has two modes for forwarded events.

segment.source: The default is “Rendered Text” which includes the textual description of the event as you would see it in Event Viewer.
segment.target: The default is “Rendered Text” which includes the textual description of the event as you would see it in Event Viewer.

segment.source: This means that the event size is effectively doubled or tripled depending on the size of the rendered description.
segment.target: This means that the event size is effectively doubled or tripled depending on the size of the rendered description.

segment.source: The alternative mode is “Events” (also sometimes referred to as “Binary” format) – which is just the event XML itself sent in binary XML format (as it would be written to the evtx file.) This is very compact and can more than double the event volume a single WEC server can accommodate.
segment.target: The alternative mode is “Events” (also sometimes referred to as “Binary” format) – which is just the event XML itself sent in binary XML format (as it would be written to the evtx file.) This is very compact and can more than double the event volume a single WEC server can accommodate.

segment.source: A subscription “testSubscription” can be configured to use the Events format through the WECUTIL utility:
segment.target: A subscription “testSubscription” can be configured to use the Events format through the WECUTIL utility:

segment.source: How frequently are WEF events delivered?
segment.target: How frequently are WEF events delivered?

segment.source: Event delivery options are part of the WEF subscription configuration parameters – There are three built-in subscription delivery options: Normal, Minimize Bandwidth, and Minimize Latency.
segment.target: Event delivery options are part of the WEF subscription configuration parameters – There are three built-in subscription delivery options: Normal, Minimize Bandwidth, and Minimize Latency.

segment.source: A fourth, catch-all called “Custom” is available but cannot be selected or configured through the WEF UI by using Event Ciewer.
segment.target: A fourth, catch-all called “Custom” is available but cannot be selected or configured through the WEF UI by using Event Ciewer.

segment.source: The Custom delivery option must be selected and configured using the WECUTIL.EXE command-line application.
segment.target: The Custom delivery option must be selected and configured using the WECUTIL.EXE command-line application.

segment.source: All subscription options define a maximum event count and maximum event age, if either limit is exceeded then the accumulated events are sent to the event collector.
segment.target: All subscription options define a maximum event count and maximum event age, if either limit is exceeded then the accumulated events are sent to the event collector.

segment.source: This table outlines the built-in delivery options:
segment.target: This table outlines the built-in delivery options:

segment.source: Event delivery optimization options
segment.target: Event delivery optimization options

segment.source: Description
segment.target: Description

segment.source: Normal
segment.target: Normal

segment.source: This option ensures reliable delivery of events and does not attempt to conserve bandwidth.
segment.target: This option ensures reliable delivery of events and does not attempt to conserve bandwidth.

segment.source: It is the appropriate choice unless you need tighter control over bandwidth usage or need forwarded events delivered as quickly as possible.
segment.target: It is the appropriate choice unless you need tighter control over bandwidth usage or need forwarded events delivered as quickly as possible.

segment.source: It uses pull delivery mode, batches 5 items at a time and sets a batch timeout of 15 minutes.
segment.target: It uses pull delivery mode, batches 5 items at a time and sets a batch timeout of 15 minutes.

segment.source: Minimize bandwidth
segment.target: Minimize bandwidth

segment.source: This option ensures that the use of network bandwidth for event delivery is strictly controlled.
segment.target: This option ensures that the use of network bandwidth for event delivery is strictly controlled.

segment.source: It is an appropriate choice if you want to limit the frequency of network connections made to deliver events.
segment.target: It is an appropriate choice if you want to limit the frequency of network connections made to deliver events.

segment.source: It uses push delivery mode and sets a batch timeout of 6 hours.
segment.target: It uses push delivery mode and sets a batch timeout of 6 hours.

segment.source: In addition, it uses a heartbeat interval of 6 hours.
segment.target: In addition, it uses a heartbeat interval of 6 hours.

segment.source: Minimize latency
segment.target: Minimize latency

segment.source: This option ensures that events are delivered with minimal delay.
segment.target: This option ensures that events are delivered with minimal delay.

segment.source: It is an appropriate choice if you are collecting alerts or critical events.
segment.target: It is an appropriate choice if you are collecting alerts or critical events.

segment.source: It uses push delivery mode and sets a batch timeout of 30 seconds.
segment.target: It uses push delivery mode and sets a batch timeout of 30 seconds.

segment.source: For more info about delivery options, see Configure Advanced Subscription Settings.
segment.target: For more info about delivery options, see Configure Advanced Subscription Settings.

segment.source: The primary difference is in the latency which events are sent from the client.
segment.target: The primary difference is in the latency which events are sent from the client.

segment.source: If none of the built-in options meet your requirements you can set Custom event delivery options for a given subscription from an elevated command prompt:
segment.target: If none of the built-in options meet your requirements you can set Custom event delivery options for a given subscription from an elevated command prompt:

segment.source: How do I control which devices have access to a WEF Subscription?
segment.target: How do I control which devices have access to a WEF Subscription?

segment.source: For source initiated subscriptions: Each WEF subscription on a WEC server has its own ACL for machine accounts or security groups containing machine accounts (not user accounts) that are explicitly allowed to participate in that subscription or are explicitly denied access.
segment.target: For source initiated subscriptions: Each WEF subscription on a WEC server has its own ACL for machine accounts or security groups containing machine accounts (not user accounts) that are explicitly allowed to participate in that subscription or are explicitly denied access.

segment.source: This ACL applies to only a single WEF subscription (since there can be multiple WEF subscriptions on a given WEC server), other WEF Subscriptions have their own separate ACL.
segment.target: This ACL applies to only a single WEF subscription (since there can be multiple WEF subscriptions on a given WEC server), other WEF Subscriptions have their own separate ACL.

segment.source: For collector initiated subscriptions: The subscription contains the list of machines from which the WEC server is to collect events.
segment.target: For collector initiated subscriptions: The subscription contains the list of machines from which the WEC server is to collect events.

segment.source: This list is managed at the WEC server, and the credentials used for the subscription must have access to read event logs from the WEF Clients – the credentials can be either the machine account or a domain account.
segment.target: This list is managed at the WEC server, and the credentials used for the subscription must have access to read event logs from the WEF Clients – the credentials can be either the machine account or a domain account.

segment.source: Can a client communicate to multiple WEF Event Collectors?
segment.target: Can a client communicate to multiple WEF Event Collectors?

segment.source: Yes.
segment.target: Yes.

segment.source: If you desire a High-Availability environment, simply configure multiple WEC servers with the same subscription configuration and publish both WEC Server URIs to WEF clients.
segment.target: If you desire a High-Availability environment, simply configure multiple WEC servers with the same subscription configuration and publish both WEC Server URIs to WEF clients.

segment.source: WEF Clients will forward events simultaneously to the configured subscriptions on the WEC servers, if they have the appropriate access.
segment.target: WEF Clients will forward events simultaneously to the configured subscriptions on the WEC servers, if they have the appropriate access.

segment.source: What are the WEC server’s limitations?
segment.target: What are the WEC server’s limitations?

segment.source: There are three factors that limit the scalability of WEC servers.
segment.target: There are three factors that limit the scalability of WEC servers.

segment.source: The general rule for a stable WEC server on commodity hardware is “10k x 10k” – meaning, no more than 10,000 concurrently active WEF Clients per WEC server and no more than 10,000 events/second average event volume.
segment.target: The general rule for a stable WEC server on commodity hardware is “10k x 10k” – meaning, no more than 10,000 concurrently active WEF Clients per WEC server and no more than 10,000 events/second average event volume.

segment.source: Disk I/O.
segment.target: Disk I/O.

segment.source: The WEC server does not process or validate the received event, but rather buffers the received event and then logs it to a local event log file (EVTX file).
segment.target: The WEC server does not process or validate the received event, but rather buffers the received event and then logs it to a local event log file (EVTX file).

segment.source: The speed of logging to the EVTX file is limited by the disk write speed.
segment.target: The speed of logging to the EVTX file is limited by the disk write speed.

segment.source: Isolating the EVTX file to its own array or using high speed disks can increase the number of events per second that a single WEC server can receive.
segment.target: Isolating the EVTX file to its own array or using high speed disks can increase the number of events per second that a single WEC server can receive.

segment.source: Network Connections.
segment.target: Network Connections.

segment.source: While a WEF source does not maintain a permanent, persistent connection to the WEC server, it does not immediately disconnect after sending its events.
segment.target: While a WEF source does not maintain a permanent, persistent connection to the WEC server, it does not immediately disconnect after sending its events.

segment.source: This means that the number of WEF sources that can simultaneously connect to the WEC server is limited to the open TCP ports available on the WEC server.
segment.target: This means that the number of WEF sources that can simultaneously connect to the WEC server is limited to the open TCP ports available on the WEC server.

segment.source: Registry size.
segment.target: Registry size.

segment.source: For each unique device that connects to a WEF subscription, there is a registry key (corresponding to the FQDN of the WEF Client) created to store bookmark and source heartbeat information.
segment.target: For each unique device that connects to a WEF subscription, there is a registry key (corresponding to the FQDN of the WEF Client) created to store bookmark and source heartbeat information.

segment.source: If this is not pruned to remove inactive clients this set of registry keys can grow to an unmanageable size over time.
segment.target: If this is not pruned to remove inactive clients this set of registry keys can grow to an unmanageable size over time.

segment.source: When a subscription has 1000 WEF sources connect to it over its operational lifetime, also known as lifetime WEF sources, Event Viewer can become unresponsive for a few minutes when selecting the Subscriptions node in the left-navigation, but will function normally afterwards.
segment.target: When a subscription has 1000 WEF sources connect to it over its operational lifetime, also known as lifetime WEF sources, Event Viewer can become unresponsive for a few minutes when selecting the Subscriptions node in the left-navigation, but will function normally afterwards.

segment.source: At 50,000 lifetime WEF sources, Event Viewer is no longer an option and wecutil.exe (included with Windows) must be used to configure and manage subscriptions.
segment.target: At 50,000 lifetime WEF sources, Event Viewer is no longer an option and wecutil.exe (included with Windows) must be used to configure and manage subscriptions.

segment.source: At 100,000 lifetime WEF sources, the registry will not be readable and the WEC server will likely have to be rebuilt.
segment.target: At 100,000 lifetime WEF sources, the registry will not be readable and the WEC server will likely have to be rebuilt.

segment.source: Subscription information
segment.target: Subscription information

segment.source: Below lists all of the items that each subscription collects, the actual subscription XML is available in an Appendix.
segment.target: Below lists all of the items that each subscription collects, the actual subscription XML is available in an Appendix.

segment.source: These are separated out into Baseline and Targeted.
segment.target: These are separated out into Baseline and Targeted.

segment.source: The intent is to subscribe all hosts to Baseline, and then enroll (and remove) hosts on an as needed basis to the Targeted subscription.
segment.target: The intent is to subscribe all hosts to Baseline, and then enroll (and remove) hosts on an as needed basis to the Targeted subscription.

segment.source: Baseline subscription
segment.target: Baseline subscription

segment.source: While this appears to be the largest subscription, it really is the lowest volume on a per-device basis.
segment.target: While this appears to be the largest subscription, it really is the lowest volume on a per-device basis.

segment.source: (Exceptions should be allowed for unusual devices – a device performing complex developer related tasks can be expected to create an unusually high volume of process create and AppLocker events.) This subscription does not require special configuration on client devices to enable event channels or modify channel permissions.
segment.target: (Exceptions should be allowed for unusual devices – a device performing complex developer related tasks can be expected to create an unusually high volume of process create and AppLocker events.) This subscription does not require special configuration on client devices to enable event channels or modify channel permissions.

segment.source: The subscription is essentially a collection of query statements applied to the Event Log.
segment.target: The subscription is essentially a collection of query statements applied to the Event Log.

segment.source: This means that it is modular in nature and a given query statement can be removed or changed without impacting other query statement in the subscription.
segment.target: This means that it is modular in nature and a given query statement can be removed or changed without impacting other query statement in the subscription.

segment.source: Additionally, suppress statements which filter out specific events, only apply within that query statement and are not to the entire subscription.
segment.target: Additionally, suppress statements which filter out specific events, only apply within that query statement and are not to the entire subscription.

segment.source: Baseline subscription requirements
segment.target: Baseline subscription requirements

segment.source: To gain the most value out of the baseline subscription we recommend to have the following requirements set on the device to ensure that the clients are already generating the required events to be forwarded off the system.
segment.target: To gain the most value out of the baseline subscription we recommend to have the following requirements set on the device to ensure that the clients are already generating the required events to be forwarded off the system.

segment.source: Apply a security audit policy that is a super-set of the recommended minimum audit policy.
segment.target: Apply a security audit policy that is a super-set of the recommended minimum audit policy.

segment.source: For more info, see Appendix A – Minimum Recommended minimum Audit Policy.
segment.target: For more info, see Appendix A – Minimum Recommended minimum Audit Policy.

segment.source: This ensures that the security event log is generating the required events.
segment.target: This ensures that the security event log is generating the required events.

segment.source: Apply at least an Audit-Only AppLocker policy to devices.
segment.target: Apply at least an Audit-Only AppLocker policy to devices.

segment.source: If you are already whitelisting or blacklisting events by using AppLocker, then this requirement is met.
segment.target: If you are already whitelisting or blacklisting events by using AppLocker, then this requirement is met.

segment.source: AppLocker events contain extremely useful information, such as file hash and digital signature information for executables and scripts.
segment.target: AppLocker events contain extremely useful information, such as file hash and digital signature information for executables and scripts.

segment.source: Enable disabled event channels and set the minimum size for modern event files.
segment.target: Enable disabled event channels and set the minimum size for modern event files.

segment.source: Currently, there is no GPO template for enabling or setting the maximum size for the modern event files.
segment.target: Currently, there is no GPO template for enabling or setting the maximum size for the modern event files.

segment.source: This must be done by using a GPO.
segment.target: This must be done by using a GPO.

segment.source: For more info, see Appendix C – Event Channel Settings (enable and Channel Access) methods.
segment.target: For more info, see Appendix C – Event Channel Settings (enable and Channel Access) methods.

segment.target: The annotated event query can be found in the following.

segment.target: For more info, see Appendix F – Annotated Baseline Subscription Event Query.

segment.source: Anti-malware events from Microsoft Antimalware or Windows Defender.
segment.target: Anti-malware events from Microsoft Antimalware or Windows Defender.

segment.source: This can be configured for any given anti-malware product easily if it writes to the Windows event log.
segment.target: This can be configured for any given anti-malware product easily if it writes to the Windows event log.

segment.source: Security event log Process Create events.
segment.target: Security event log Process Create events.

segment.source: OS startup and shutdown
segment.target: OS startup and shutdown

segment.source: Startup event include operating system version, service pack level, QFE version, and boot mode.
segment.target: Startup event include operating system version, service pack level, QFE version, and boot mode.

segment.source: Service install
segment.target: Service install

segment.source: Includes what the name of the service, the image path, and who installed the service.
segment.target: Includes what the name of the service, the image path, and who installed the service.

segment.source: Certificate Authority audit events
segment.target: Certificate Authority audit events

segment.source: This is only applicable on systems with the Certificate Authority role installed.
segment.target: This is only applicable on systems with the Certificate Authority role installed.

segment.source: Logs certificate requests and responses.
segment.target: Logs certificate requests and responses.

segment.source: User profile events
segment.target: User profile events

segment.source: Use of a temporary profile or unable to create a user profile may indicate an intruder is interactively logging into a device but not wanting to leave a persistent profile behind.
segment.target: Use of a temporary profile or unable to create a user profile may indicate an intruder is interactively logging into a device but not wanting to leave a persistent profile behind.

segment.source: Service start failure
segment.target: Service start failure

segment.source: Failure codes are localized, so you have to check the message DLL for values.
segment.target: Failure codes are localized, so you have to check the message DLL for values.

segment.source: Network share access events
segment.target: Network share access events

segment.source: Filter out IPC$ and /NetLogon file shares, which are expected and noisy.
segment.target: Filter out IPC$ and /NetLogon file shares, which are expected and noisy.

segment.source: System shutdown initiate requests
segment.target: System shutdown initiate requests

segment.source: Find out what initiated the restart of a device.
segment.target: Find out what initiated the restart of a device.

segment.target: User initiated interactive logoff event

segment.source: Remote Desktop Services session connect, reconnect, or disconnect.
segment.target: Remote Desktop Services session connect, reconnect, or disconnect.

segment.source: EMET events, if EMET is installed.

segment.target: Event forwarding plugin events

segment.source: For monitoring WEF subscription operations, particularly Partial Success events.
segment.target: For monitoring WEF subscription operations, particularly Partial Success events.

segment.source: This is useful for diagnosing deployment issues.
segment.target: This is useful for diagnosing deployment issues.

segment.source: Network share create and delete
segment.target: Network share create and delete

segment.source: Enables detection of unauthorized share creation.
segment.target: Enables detection of unauthorized share creation.

segment.source: Note: All shares are re-created when the device starts.
segment.target: Note: All shares are re-created when the device starts.

segment.source: Logon sessions
segment.target: Logon sessions

segment.source: Logon success for interactive (local and Remote Interactive/Remote Desktop)
segment.target: Logon success for interactive (local and Remote Interactive/Remote Desktop)

segment.source: Logon success for services for non-built-in accounts, such as LocalSystem, LocalNetwork, and so on.
segment.target: Logon success for services for non-built-in accounts, such as LocalSystem, LocalNetwork, and so on.

segment.source: Logon success for batch sessions
segment.target: Logon success for batch sessions

segment.source: Logon session close, which are logoff events for non-network sessions.
segment.target: Logon session close, which are logoff events for non-network sessions.

segment.source: Windows Error Reporting (Application crash events only)
segment.target: Windows Error Reporting (Application crash events only)

segment.source: This can help detect early signs of intruder not familiar with enterprise environment using targeted malware.
segment.target: This can help detect early signs of intruder not familiar with enterprise environment using targeted malware.

segment.source: Event log service events
segment.target: Event log service events

segment.source: Errors, start events, and stop events for the Windows Event Log service.
segment.target: Errors, start events, and stop events for the Windows Event Log service.

segment.source: Event log cleared (including the Security Event Log)
segment.target: Event log cleared (including the Security Event Log)

segment.source: This could indicate an intruder that are covering their tracks.
segment.target: This could indicate an intruder that are covering their tracks.

segment.target: Special privileges assigned to new logon

segment.source: This indicates that at the time of logon a user is either an Administrator or has the sufficient access to make themselves Administrator.

segment.target: Gives visibility to groups which enable account wide access

segment.source: Allows better planning for remediation efforts
segment.target: Allows better planning for remediation efforts

segment.source: Excludes well known, built-in system accounts.
segment.target: Excludes well known, built-in system accounts.

segment.target: Logon session exit

segment.source: Specific for network logon sessions.

segment.target: Local credential validation or logon with explicit credentials

segment.target: Noisy on domain controllers

segment.target: On client devices this is only generated when local accounts log on.

segment.source: Appendix B - Recommended minimum registry system ACL policy
segment.target: Appendix B - Recommended minimum registry system ACL policy

segment.source: The Run and RunOnce keys are useful for intruders and malware persistence.
segment.target: The Run and RunOnce keys are useful for intruders and malware persistence.

segment.source: It allows code to be run (or run only once then removed, respectively) when a user logs into the system.
segment.target: It allows code to be run (or run only once then removed, respectively) when a user logs into the system.

segment.source: This can easily be extended to other Auto-Execution Start Points keys in the registry.
segment.target: This can easily be extended to other Auto-Execution Start Points keys in the registry.

segment.source: Use the following figures to see how you can configure those registry keys.
segment.target: Use the following figures to see how you can configure those registry keys.

segment.source: default acl for run key
segment.target: default acl for run key

segment.source: default acl for runonce key
segment.target: default acl for runonce key

segment.source: Appendix C - Event channel settings (enable and channel access) methods
segment.target: Appendix C - Event channel settings (enable and channel access) methods

segment.source: Some channels are disabled by default and have to be enabled.
segment.target: Some channels are disabled by default and have to be enabled.

segment.source: Others, such as Microsoft-Windows-CAPI2/Operational must have the channel access modified to allow the Event Log Readers built-in security group to read from it.
segment.target: Others, such as Microsoft-Windows-CAPI2/Operational must have the channel access modified to allow the Event Log Readers built-in security group to read from it.

segment.source: The recommended and most effective way to do this is to configure the baseline GPO to run a scheduled task to configure the event channels (enable, set maximum size, and adjust channel access.) This will take effect at the next GPO refresh cycle and has minimal impact on the client device.
segment.target: The recommended and most effective way to do this is to configure the baseline GPO to run a scheduled task to configure the event channels (enable, set maximum size, and adjust channel access.) This will take effect at the next GPO refresh cycle and has minimal impact on the client device.

segment.source: The following GPO snippet performs the following:
segment.target: The following GPO snippet performs the following:

segment.source: Enables the Microsoft-Windows-Capi2/Operational event channel.
segment.target: Enables the Microsoft-Windows-Capi2/Operational event channel.

segment.source: Sets the maximum file size for Microsoft-Windows-Capi2/Operational to 100MB.
segment.target: Sets the maximum file size for Microsoft-Windows-Capi2/Operational to 100MB.

segment.source: Sets the maximum file size for Microsoft-Windows-AppLocker/EXE and DLL to 100MB.
segment.target: Sets the maximum file size for Microsoft-Windows-AppLocker/EXE and DLL to 100MB.

segment.source: Sets the maximum channel access for Microsoft-Windows-Capi2/Operational to include the built-in Event Log Readers security group.
segment.target: Sets the maximum channel access for Microsoft-Windows-Capi2/Operational to include the built-in Event Log Readers security group.

segment.source: Enables the Microsoft-Windows-DriverFrameworks-UserMode/Operational event channel.
segment.target: Enables the Microsoft-Windows-DriverFrameworks-UserMode/Operational event channel.

segment.source: Sets the maximum file size for Microsoft-Windows-DriverFrameworks-UserMode/Operational to 50MB.
segment.target: Sets the maximum file size for Microsoft-Windows-DriverFrameworks-UserMode/Operational to 50MB.

segment.source: configure event channels
segment.target: configure event channels

segment.source: Appendix D - Minimum GPO for WEF Client configuration
segment.target: Appendix D - Minimum GPO for WEF Client configuration

segment.source: Here are the minimum steps for WEF to operate:
segment.target: Here are the minimum steps for WEF to operate:

segment.source: Configure the collector URI(s).
segment.target: Configure the collector URI(s).

segment.source: Start the WinRM service.
segment.target: Start the WinRM service.

segment.source: Add the Network Service account to the built-in Event Log Readers security group.
segment.target: Add the Network Service account to the built-in Event Log Readers security group.

segment.source: This allows reading from secured event channel, such as the security event channel.
segment.target: This allows reading from secured event channel, such as the security event channel.

segment.source: configure the wef client
segment.target: configure the wef client
